Circuit: a single-stage common-source amplifier with resistive load R
A three-stage amplifier with single input and output (each stage is common-source with resistive load)
A common-drain amplifier (a.k.a. a source follower) with resistive load R (output Vout at the source)
A single-stage common-gate amplifier with resistive load R (input signal Vin must be applied at the source terminal)
A single-stage cascode amplifier with two NMOS transistors provides a single-ended output through a resistive load R
A NMOS inverter with resistive load R
A logical inverter with 1 NMOS and 1 PMOS
A simple NMOS constant current source with resistive load R
an op-amp comparator to make the output high when Vin > Vref and low when Vin < Vref
Testbench: The testbench applies a 0-5V sweep signal to Vin.
Normal: Vout should transition sharply from low to high when the input voltage exceeds the reference voltage, producing a digital signal with two states.

Circuit: a passive low-pass filter
Testbench: The testbench applies a 1Hz-1GHz frequency sweep signal to Vin.
Normal: Vout should show minimal attenuation at low frequencies and progressively decrease in amplitude as frequency increases.

Circuit: a passive high-pass filter
Testbench: The testbench applies a 1Hz-1GHz frequency sweep signal to Vin.
Normal: Vout should show significant attenuation at low frequencies and increase to full amplitude at higher frequencies.

Circuit: a passive band-pass filter
Testbench: The testbench applies a 1Hz-1GHz frequency sweep signal to Vin.
Normal: Vout should show attenuation at both low and high frequencies, with maximum amplitude occurring within a specific frequency range.

Circuit: a passive band-stop filter
Testbench: The testbench applies a 1Hz-1GHz frequency sweep signal to Vin.
Normal: Vout should show normal signal transmission across most frequencies but exhibit a distinct attenuation within a specific frequency range.

Circuit: A two-stage amplifier with a Miller compensation capacitor
A single-stage amplifier (common-source with PMOS diode-connected load (gate and drain are shorted))
A differential opamp with an active PMOS current mirror load, a tail current source, and two outputs
A cascode current mirror with 4 mosfets (2 stacked at input side with diode-connected, 2 stacked at output side), reference current source input Iref (connected to Vdd) and resistive load R
A single-stage differential common-source opamp with dual resistive loads, tail current, and a single output
A Gilbert cell mixer to make Voutp - Voutn ∝ (Vrfp - Vrfn) × (Vlop - Vlon)
Testbench: The testbench provides two sets of differential input signals to the Gilbert Cell mixer: 1.2kHz LO signals (Vlop-Vlon) and 1kHz RF signals (Vrfp-Vrfn).
Normal: The Voutp and Voutn differential outputs should produce an FFT spectrum showing two primary mixing products: a 200Hz component representing down-conversion (|LO-RF|) and a 2.2kHz component representing up-conversion (LO+RF).

Circuit: A two-stage differential opamp (first stage: common-source with an active load and a tail current, second stage: common-source with an active load)
A single-stage telescopic cascode opamp with two outputs (4 nmos as cascode input pair, 4 pmos as cascode loads, and 1 tail current)
Input: Vinp, Vinn, Vbias1, Vbias2, Vbias3, Vbias4

Circuit: An RC phase-shift oscillator
Testbench: The testbench initializes the op-amp non-inverting input (Vinp) to 2.51V and the inverting input (Vinn) to 2.5V.

Circuit: A Wien Bridge oscillator
Testbench: The testbench initializes the op-amp non-inverting input (Vinp) to 2.51V and the inverting input (Vinn) to 2.5V.

Circuit: An Opamp integrator with resistor R1 and capacitor Cf
Testbench: The testbench inputs a square wave to Vin.
Normal: Vout should output a triangle wave.

Circuit: An Opamp differentiator with resistor Rf and capacitor C1
Testbench: The testbench inputs a triangle wave to Vin.
Normal: Vout should output a square wave.

Circuit: An Opamp adder to make Vout=-(Vin1+Vin2)
An Op-amp subtractor to make Vout=Vin2-Vin1
A non-inverting Schmitt trigger with positive feedback op-map
Testbench: The testbench inputs a sine wave at Vin.
Normal: The output (Vout) should be a square wave.

Circuit: a Wien-bridge voltage‑controlled oscillator (Op-Amp based, RC network, no diodes)
Testbench: The testbench initializes the op-amp non-inverting input (Vinp) to 2.51V and the inverting input (Vinn) to 2.5V.
Normal: Vout should oscillate periodically, with its frequency varying according to Vctrl.
